title: About this module
body:
Have you ever wondered why some people seem able to easily move on from their mistakes and aren’t bothered by their own shortcomings, while others judge themselves harshly and get bogged down in negative self-talk and criticism? If you’re someone who tends to negatively self-criticise but is looking for ways to be kinder to yourself, this module is for you.


We’ll focus on how to build a healthy mindset and developing stronger self-compassion to help reduce stress and increase effectiveness at work and home. By the end of this module, you’ll be able to:


  • Describe self-compassion and why it’s important
  • Practise activities in daily life to build your self-compassion


We expect that this module will take approximately 20 minutes to complete. Your progress is saved as you go. If you need to take a break, you can always pick up where you left off later.

title: Further practice and learning
body: You may now save and exit this module.

title: Congratulations
body:
Self-compassion is actually a super-power that will help you be more confident and less stressed, because it enables you to meet your own needs and bounce back when things don’t go well.


You can build the skills of tender self-compassion by talking to yourself with kind and supportive words instead of harsh ones, and you can soothe your own nervous system with gentle touch.


You’ve made a plan to practise fierce self-compassion in your day-to-day life, prioritising meeting your own needs when you’re suffering and protecting your own boundaries when other people want to take more from you than you’re willing to give.

title: Healthy Mindset Self-assessment
body:
Are you someone who’s kind to or tough on yourself?


Complete this short survey and check the health of your current mindset.

_items.body: Q1 I’m disapproving and judgemental about my own flaws.
Q2 When I fail at something I become consumed by feelings of inadequacy.
Q3 When I feel emotional pain, I’m harder on myself than I would be on someone else who was in pain.
Q4 When I think about my inadequacies, it tends to make me feel more separate and cut off from the rest of the world.

title: Make a plan
body: Make a plan of small steps you can take to prioritise your needs and build protective boundaries over the next week. At the end of the week, review your plan and the impact of the steps you’ve taken. Don’t be disheartened if you don’t see much of a difference after the first week – remember, it takes time and repetition to change your own patterns. It’s worth making the effort because if you succeed, you’ll probably feel a lot better and less tired and stressed by the end of the week because you’ve ‘filled and protected your own cup’ instead of pouring too much into other people and obligations.

title: Text Title
body:
This might look like saying ‘no’ when you’re asked to take on more work when you’re already over capacity, or to holding your own in a situation where someone is being pushy and aggressive. 


Identifying where your boundaries could be stronger will enable you to know where opportunities to practise fierce self-compassion lie.

title: Reframing critical thoughts
body:
When a harsh thought pops up, it can be helpful to reframe it with a more positive one. You can do this in your head or out loud, or you can write it down. Practise is the key because the more you do it, the more your brain will remember this kinder way of thinking.


Select the buttons to hear an example of a harsh thought reframed as a kinder and more helpful one or alternatively select the transcript button.

title: Determine Your Priorities
body: Tender self-compassion is a skill that can be built with intentional and regular practise. We’ll now explore activities that can be practised at work or at home as needed, for example when you’re feeling stressed or upset, or at a regular time each day, for example in the evening before bed.

title: Did you know?
body:
Did you know?


Buddhist monks learn how to practise self-compassion as part of their training.

title: Benefits of practising self-compassion
body:
Practising self-compassion can bring many benefits to your life, both at work and at home.


Select the flip cards to see what self-compassion can do for you.

_items.backText:
Self-compassion can help you identify,
validate and move through difficult 
emotions instead of getting stuck 
in them.

Self-compassion can help you move 
through the stages of feeling 
emotionally overwhelmed to solution 
mode, to overcoming problems and 
achieving your goals.

Research indicates that people who
practise self-compassion are better
able to cope with stress; they’re less
likely to catastrophise negative
situations or experience anxiety after a
stressful event.

People who practise self-compassion
are more willing to lean into challenges
and less likely to be held back by fear
of failure.

title: Text Title
body:
The first step to practising fierce self-compassion is being able to think carefully and identify your own needs, especially in moments of suffering or stress. Reflect on how your needs change in response to different situations and emotions and be as specific as possible.


For example, if you get a rude email that makes you angry, what you might need is a 10-minute power walk or to vent to a friend. If you’re feeling overwhelmed by too much work, you might need a quiet space to take some deep breaths and practise soothing touch and kind self-talk.

title: Text Title
body:
This module introduces thinking and feeling exercises you can practise at home and work. A lot of people find these exercises to be gentle and empowering. 


However, there’s a risk that you may experience unpleasant feelings or thoughts when trying some of these practices, especially if you have a history of trauma or are experiencing significant hardship in your life.

title: Text Title
body:
As such, we recommend you identify a compassionate friend or family member you can talk to if difficult thoughts and feelings come up, and where you feel it necessary, consider the additional support of a trained counsellor or therapist to provide professional support.


If you feel distressed all while working through the module or exercises, stop what you’re doing and take a self-care break, like a walk, gentle breathing, or doing an activity you like. Only return to the module if/when you feel confident and appropriately supported.


You can also access support from:


  • The employee assistance services offered by your workplace 
  • Your leader/supervisor or HR representative
  • Private counsellors
  • A general practitioner
  • Lifeline on 131114

_transcript.body:
When we try to understand the concept of self-compassion, it can be helpful to first think of compassion - what it is and how it feels. 


Compassion can be defined as feelings of kindness towards, and a desire to help, someone who's suffering. Imagine how you'd react if a good friend told you about some upsetting news they'd received and they were clearly distressed. If your reaction was to feel concerned and want to help them, that's compassion. 


Self-compassion is applying the same sense of loving concern to ourselves, especially at times when life is hard and stressful. Most of us are great at feeling and acting on our compassion for others, but when it comes to ourselves, we can be tough and uncaring. Sometimes we don't even realise we are suffering because we're so focused on other people's needs or getting things done. 


Self-compassion is also about taking a balanced and mindful perspective of things. Seeing the bigger picture beyond a moment of suffering, instead of ignoring our pain or exaggerating it. 


When we are compassionate to ourselves, we recognise that suffering is part of the human experience that connects us all, rather than something that isolates us or means we are flawed or unworthy.

title: Media Title
body:
Self-compassion is key to building a healthy mindset, however it can be a tricky concept to get your head around and some people who are new to self-compassion can mistakenly see it as a weakness that makes them ‘soft’ or selfish.


Select the play button to watch this animation explaining the concept of self-compassion or alternatively select the transcript button.

title: Tender vs fierce self-compassion

_items.title: Tender self-compassion
_items.body:
Tender self-compassion is the ‘gentle parent’ side of self-compassion where we validate our own pain and give ourselves reassurance and comfort. 


For example, imagine you missed out on a promotion that you really wanted and felt you deserved. Tender self-compassion might sound like saying the following things to yourself:

  • “I feel really shocked and disappointed right now and it hurts.” (Validation)
  • “Just because I missed out on getting the role this time, doesn’t mean I’m not worthy of it. I know how good I am at this work. I can continue to prove my worth and have another go at it in six months.” (Reassurance)
  • “What do I need right now to help soothe this painful emotion? I think a cup of tea and a chat with my best friend will help.” (Comfort)

_items.title: Fierce self-compassion
_items.body:
Fierce self-compassion is the powerful action-oriented side that protects, provides for, and motivates us. 


Fierce self-compassion looks like:

  • Saying ‘no’ to someone who’s trying to hurt us
  • Giving ourselves what we need instead of putting others first
  • Making changes to our lives and society to reduce suffering

body:
Dr Neff’s work has defined two sides to self-compassion: tender and fierce. 


Select each plus (+) button to read the descriptions of the two types of self-compassion.

title: Audio 1

_transcript.body:
“Well, that was such a stupid thing to say. Why can’t you just shut up in these meetings.”

“Everyone’s staring at you, thinking you’re pathetic.”

“Come on, you useless piece of trash. Get on with it already.”

body:
As well as the benefits we just explored, self-compassion is also your number one weapon to combat the harsh words of your inner critic — that voice in your head that censures, finds fault, judges and demeans you.


Select the audio button to hear some examples of what an inner critic voice might say or alternatively select the transcript button.

title: Audio 2

_transcript.body:
“Damn, that comment didn’t come out how I intended it, I feel a bit embarrassed. Oh well, everyone has moved on and they probably barely noticed.” 

“I’m really struggling to get motivated today. Maybe if I just do 15 minutes work now and then take a break, at least I’ll have started.”

body:
We develop self-critical thinking patterns as a way of trying to keep ourselves in check, on track and safe, but there can be times when this way of thinking doesn’t serve us as intended and can make things harder and more stressful for us. Self-compassion helps us replace our harsh, criticising internal voice with a kinder and more constructive one.


Select the audio button to listen to some examples of what a more self-compassionate inner voice might say or alternatively select the transcript button.

title: Did you know? (inner critic)
body:
Did you know? 


Culture has a role in shaping our tendency to be self-critical. In Thailand, where Buddhism is popular, people tend to be more self-compassionate. In Western and Eastern cultures, where Confucian ideals are prevalent, people are more likely to use self-criticism as a means of motivation.

title: Common myths

_items.body: Research indicates that self-criticism is strongly related to depression and dissatisfaction with life. Conversely, self-compassion helps you cope with difficult emotions, get a balanced perspective and move forward towards goals.
_items.title: I need to be hard on myself to succeed

_items.body:
Self-pity is typically characterised by seeing yourself as a victim and placing blame on others or external circumstances. Someone experiencing self-pity may get stuck in a state of misery, waiting for someone else to fix things for them. 


Self-compassion differs significantly from self-pity in that it empowers you to act and change your circumstances to ease your own suffering.
_items.title: Self-compassion leads to self-pity

_items.body: People who practise self-compassion can feel more compassion for others and research indicates that this can lead to improved relationships and greater connectedness.
_items.title: Self-compassion will make me selfish

body:
People can be sceptical of self-compassion because they think it could lead to developing negative habits and traits instead of positive ones.


Select the headings to bust these common myths.

title: Audio Harsh thought

_transcript.body: “You blew that presentation you idiot. Why didn’t you prepare and practice more? Now the client and your manager think you’re totally incompetent, which you clearly are!”

body: Harsh thought

title: Reframing critical thoughts final text
body: You can see from the examples that the harsh thoughts are unlikely to fix anything and may make you feel even worse. On the other hand, the compassionate thoughts can help you recognise the tough emotions, allow them to pass and give you the headspace to move on to practical next steps.

title: Creating a compassionate vision
body:
For some of us, trying to practise self-compassion can bring up feelings of fear and vulnerability, which can become a roadblock to treating ourselves kindly. 


In these instances, it can be helpful to use a visualisation practice, where you imagine someone who embodies a compassionate energy sitting with you, listening to your troubles and sending you warmth and concern.


A lot of people use the image of someone older with a kind wise face, a place in nature like a large old tree, or a beloved pet. You could also bring to mind the most kind-hearted and compassionate person you know and visualise their presence with you.


Research has indicated that practising this exercise can help generate feelings of safety and warmth that then enable you to practise building your self-compassion skills.

_transcript.body:
Soothing Touch


Hi, I'm Cat, and I'm gonna show you some soothing touch exercises you can use to calm your nervous system. 


[Text on screen: Hand on heart]


The first is to simply put your hand over your heart. You can experiment with how much pressure feels good here. Some people like firm pressure or even a fist with the other hand over the top. Other people like me, like a gentler touch and even some soft, soothing motion. 


[Text on screen: Hand on stomach]


Next, you can try putting your hand over your stomach, or two hands on your stomach, or one on your chest and one on your stomach. Play around with these to see which feels best for you. 


[Text on screen: Self-hug]


The next is a self-hug. Where you simply wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big squeeze, as if you would a friend who is having a tough day. Lots of people find this really comforting and containing. And it can be quite discreet if you want to try it out in a meeting. 


[Text on screen: Gentle strokes]


The last one, which is my favourite, is to gently caress your skin. I like to run my fingertips really lightly across the skin on my face or down the back of my neck, and even through my hair. Your skin's full of nerve endings that you can use to send a signal to your brain that you're safe and you can relax, and all those stress hormones can melt away. 


So, there you have it. Those are some exercises that use the power of the body to calm the brain.

title: Using soothing touch
body:
Practising self-compassion isn’t just a mental exercise, you can also use soothing physical touch to activate your internal care-giving system and release oxytocin — the ‘love and bonding’ chemical which increases feelings of warmth and compassion, soothing emotions and cardiovascular stress.


Select the play button to watch a video demonstrating forms of compassionate soothing touch you can try out or alternatively select the transcript button.

title: Text Title
body:
Fierce self-compassion is all about acting in the world to alleviate suffering. It can be helpful to think of it as a fierce mother lion who provides for, protects and motivates her offspring. Doing this for yourself is a powerful way to foster wellbeing. 


We’ll now explore strategies you can use to improve your fierce self-compassion.

title: Audio Title

_transcript.body:
“I’m sorry but I don’t have capacity to help you today. I could help tomorrow morning?” 

“In future I’d appreciate it if you could wait until business hours to contact me about work matters.”

“I know it’s not a big task, but I’m afraid I won’t be able to do it for you. It’s outside my responsibilities and it’s important we stick to the agreed process.”

body: Select the audio button to hear examples of what assertively setting boundaries can sound like or alternatively select the transcript button.

title: Text Title
body:
Once you know what your needs and boundaries are, an important next step is assertively communicating these to the people around you.


For example, if it’s important to you to keep work and home separate, you can make sure your manager and co-workers know that you don’t want to be called or emailed outside of work hours unless it’s an emergency.


Practise saying things out loud by yourself and begin with ‘small win’ conversations that have the lowest risk of someone reacting badly. As you gain confidence, you can seek out resources and support to build the skills for setting boundaries with more challenging people/situations.

title: Audio Asking your critical voice for space

_transcript.body: “Hey, I know you’re trying to protect me, but harsh words are not helping. If you give me some space, I’ll figure this out.”

body:
When your critical voice is giving you a hard time, it can be powerful to respectfully ask it to ease up. 


Select the audio button to hear an example of what you might say to your critic or alternatively select the transcript button.

title: History of self-compassion
body:
The concept of self-compassion comes from early Buddhist meditative practices. In the early 2000s, research by Dr Kristen Neff further elaborated on this concept and brought it into contemporary Western practice. 


There are now over 3,500 research papers on self-compassion and the concepts and techniques are taught all over the world to help people with their wellbeing. 


Research results consistently show that self-compassion is a powerful way to build strength, coping strategies and resilience.

title: Text Title
body:
Another way to build your compassionate self-talk skills is to write yourself a letter about something that’s causing you pain or stress in life. 


Here are some prompts you can use in the letter to foster a compassionate tone:


  • Dear …
  • I’m writing to you because …
  • I’m sorry you have to go through this …
  • I hope you know …
  • I’m wondering have you thought about …
  • Please know I …
  • With love, …
displayTitle: Writing a compassionate letter to yourself

title: Text Title
body:
Keeping a practice journal is a great way to build your skills and also to track your progress over time. At the end if this module you’ll find a Building a healthy mindset practice journal that contains a series of self-compassion practise activities.


If you don’t like writing in a journal, recording video or audio blogs for yourself is also a great way to practise these skills.

title: Action plan
body: Action plan - Actions I’m going to take in the next two weeks to better meet my needs and protect my boundaries are …
instruction: Type your response in the box below and then select Save.

title: Communication
body: Communication - Things I can say to people I work with/live with/socialise with to help them better understand my needs and boundaries are …
instruction: Type your response in the box below and then select Save.

title: My boundaries
body: My boundaries - The situations that cause me stress or distress that I’d like to say ‘no’ to in future are …
instruction: Type your response in the box below and then select Save.

title: My needs
body: My needs - When I’m feeling stressed or difficult emotions like sadness, anger, frustration, isolation, what I need is …
instruction: Type your response in the box below and then select Save.

_transcript.body:
Dear Mark, 


I'm writing to you because I know you're really stressed out about restructure and uncertainty of your role. I'm sorry you have to go through this. It's awful not knowing if your job is secure and you're powerless to do anything about it. 


I hope you know, I have total faith in your ability to get through this. You're smart, talented, experienced and creative. You'll bounce back no matter what happens. 


I'm wondering if you've thought about dedicating a bit more time to your own self-care. If you do some of the things you really enjoy more often, it'll help with the stress. Please know I'm proud of you and I'm always here for you.

title: compassionate letter video
body: Select the play button to see an example of a compassionate letter or alternatively select the transcript button.

title: Congratulations
body:
Well done, you’re on your way to building a kinder, healthier mindset.


In this module, you’ve explored what self-compassion is and how you can start to practise it at home and work.

title: Compassionate thought

_transcript.body: “Oh man that didn’t go well, and I feel ashamed that I let the team down. But it’s just one presentation and everyone has off days. If I call the client tomorrow, I can repair the damage to my reputation and keep the relationship strong. The bright side is I’ve learnt a lot from this about how I can better prepare for the next one.”

body: Compassionate thought

title: Text Title
body:
Think about times where you need to draw more boundaries in your life to protect yourself against intentional or unintentional harm.


For example, are there times when you say ‘yes’ to doing things you don’t want to do even though saying ‘no’ is a viable option? Saying ‘no’ can be a powerful form of self-compassion which protects and preserves your energy for your own needs, instead of giving it all away to other people’s demands.

title: Text Title
displayTitle: Asking your critical voice for space

title: Text Title
body:
Complete your own fierce self-compassion practise plan which you can then download and save.


You need to save entries in all text boxes to be able to download your plan. It’s recommended that you complete this plan in one sitting because the plan will be reset if you exit the module, and you’ll need to re-enter your responses.

title: Journal button
body: To further develop your self-compassion skills, download and save or print your plan.

title: Download practise journal
body:
To continue building a healthy mindset you can learn more from Dr Kirsten Neff’s website Self-Compassion which contains many useful, free articles and videos.


You can also download and save or print a copy of the Building a healthy mindset practice journal. Use the journal to further practise your self-compassion skills and record your reflections as you go.
